title: Do you consider that people nowadays mistake comfort for happiness? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes. Comfort is a form of pleasure, which is often mistaken for happiness; it “pleases” the senses. Pleasure seeking in our culture has become endemic in many forms from food, to alcohol, fashion, body image, drugs, sex, power, living conditions, cars, and other things. The problem with ““pleasure seeking” is there is never enough to keep us satisfied or content; we constantly want more: ““super sized” beverages, “double burger”, “the works”, “the best”, “fastest”, etc. Of course, “comfort” is relative, and for a homeless person, it might be a piece of cardboard. For others, it might be a 20 room mansion with a staff of 8. The real question is “want vs. need”. unfortunately, our culture has glorified certain lifestyles as the goal in life to find happiness; all of which are heavy on comfort. Its definitely more “comfortable” to fly on a private jet, than to deal with the hassle of airports and crowded planes. But, do we really need it? Problems like crowded airports are simply a normal part of life, as is waiting in line at the drivers license office. If we construct the mental picture that “we” shouldn’t have to endure this violation of our time and comfort, we are creating a mind set for constant frustration, anger, and unhappiness. When we realistically ask ourselves what “comforts” we actually need, they are not much, and simpler is better. We didn’t need a flashy, expensive car to go shopping, or see the doctor; they cost too much, and get beat up in parking lots. We don’t need a lavish home, when something simple, secure, quiet, and warm will suffice. We don’t need an “haute cuisine” meal, when all we really need is nourishment. Do we: “live to eat, or eat to live”? simple things are truly more beneficial for happiness because we are no longer shackled by a constant quest for something better (which we don’t actually “need”). There’s an old adage attributed to Ghandi that is appropriate here: “There is always enough for need, but never enough for greed”. Metta
